prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The required sensitivity is based on the predictions of our generic gas disk model for the CO lines for a low mass disk of 0.001 Msol (see Figure 4 in main text). Assuming typical weather conditions (0.9 mm for Band 7), we find a rms level of 3.4 mJy/beam per 1 km/s channel for 31+17 minutes (extended+compact) on source integration. Since the main goal of these observations is to constrain the density and kinematic structure of the gas our S/N demands are based on detecting at least 12CO 3-2 and 13CO 3-2 in the outer disk at high spatial resolution. Since we require uniform settings for the entire sample for direct comparison, the same sensitivity is used for all disks and higher mass disks are likely to detect also C18O 3-2 for even better density constraints.
Of particular interest is the amount of gas inside the cavity compared to the outer disk. Our sensitivity limit shows that a drop in gas density can be detected for a range of values down to a factor 10^5, corresponding to less than an Earth mass (for a 0.001 Msol disk).
The continuum bandwidth (combining both spectral settings) is ~6 GHz, resulting in rms levels of 44 microJy/beam. This means that the S/N on the continuum is expected to be ~400, resulting in very good image quality. This allows detailed analysis of the structure of the millimeter-dust continuum and in particular the shape of the dust cavity wall, which can be compared directly with dust evolution models. Also, there is a possibility of detecting azimuthal asymmetries with contrasts up to a factor 100. The combination of high S/N with the 0.1" angular resolution also provides firm constraints on the peak position of the continuum, which can be used for motion studies of the dust asymmetries with ALMA in 10-20 years.

In order to have sufficient velocity resolution and maximize the continuum sensitivity, the basebands containing lines are set to FDM mode with 0.25 km/s resolution (282 kHz in Band 7). Spectral averaging is set to reduce the data rate below 12 Mb/s.
In addition to the CO isotopologues we target several other diagnostic lines, which have been chosen based on the frequency of the CO line. The 13CO 3-2 and C18O 3-2 frequencies of 330 GHz combine well with the CN 3-2 line. Two broad continuum windows are set to look for serendipitous lines. The detection or non-detection of the targeted lines will constrain several physical and chemical properties in the disk.

The 0.1" resolution is required to properly resolve the cavities in dust and gas. The configuration is chosen based on the line observations as a compromise between the highest spatial resolution required for our science goals and the expected strength of the emission. If only the extended configuration is used, emission on scales larger than 1.4" will be resolved out, whereas several disks studied in earlier ALMA cycles are shown to have emission up to 6" angular scales. Therefore, a combination of compact and extended is required for proper imaging of the disks.

The required sensitivity is based on the predictions of our generic gas disk model for the CO lines for a low mass disk of 0.001 Msol (see Figure 4 in main text). In addition to the CO isotopologues we target several other diagnostic lines, which have been chosen based on the frequency of the CO line. prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Transitional disks with large dust cavities are considered the best laboratories to study disk evolution and planet formation. ALMA has revolutionized our view of these disks through a range of high impact scientific discoveries such as dust traps, dynamical clearing by planets and complex molecules. In Cycle 3, ALMA will reach the sensitivity and spatial resolution needed to study the gas and dust in these disks at the level of theoretical models and optical/infrared images. We therefore propose to observe a significant sample of the most well-studied transition disks with large cavities at 0.1" resolution in 12CO, 13CO and C18O 3-2, 345 GHz continuum and additional lines, to constrain their structure to unprecedented level. This is one of three complementary proposals from the EU, Chile and NA partners that aims to study 20 disks in total. These are submitted by a consortium that consists of more than 60 members, experts in all relevant fields in disk studies, both theoretical and observational. The goal is to produce uniform datasets that will be available to all members of the consortium when they are acquired, and to the general community after a 3 months proprietary period.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
